title: Why inheritance tax is here to stay, despite decades of Tory promises
text:
When Sajid Javid, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, hinted at the Conservative Party conference this week that scrapping inheritance tax was “on his mind”, he was merely taking his place in a long line of political panderers playing the ace.

In 1996, Ken Clarke promised to abolish the dreaded tax just 10 years after it had been introduced, calling it “a penalty on thrift, independence and enterprise”. Reader, he did not.

Roughly a decade later, in 2007, shadow chancellor George Osborne promised to raise the tax-free threshold from £325,000 to £1m should the Tories come to power. Reader, he did not.
